intro: Acaena fissistipula var. rubristigma, commonly known as the red-stigma bristled burr, is a species of flowering plant native to New Zealand. It is a member of the Rosaceae family and is characterized by its spiny, spherical fruits that contain seeds. The plant typically grows in coastal and subalpine regions, where it thrives in well-drained soils. Its foliage consists of small, alternate leaves with a hairy texture, and it produces yellowish-green flowers in the spring. The variety rubristigma is distinguished by its reddish stigmas, which give it its common name.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acaena fissistipula var. rubristigma is primarily native to New Zealand. It is found in the South Island, particularly in the regions of Canterbury and Otago. This plant typically grows in rocky or gravelly soils, often in open vegetation types such as tussock grasslands. It is commonly associated with coastal and inland areas, thriving in well-drained environments. The variety is distinguished by its red-stippled leaves, which give it its specific name *rubristigma*.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acaena fissistipula var. rubristigma was mainly introduced to New Zealand. It was brought there as part of the broader introduction of the Acaena genus for ornamental purposes. The plant has since become naturalized in various regions of the country. It is commonly found in disturbed soils and along roadsides. However, it is considered a potential weed in some areas due to its ability to spread rapidly.
